<s>that there are no less than Eight kinds of rectilinear* prismatic coloured phenomena 
which may be produced between the plane surfaces of glass 
plates of a parallel or uniform thickness, which if not absolutely 
different in kind are so at least either in appearance, or in the 
manner of their production; none of which have yet been 
publickly noticed, either by Newton or any other writer. 
These various phenomena naturally divide themselves 
into two genera, which without impropriety may be demominated 
primary & Binary+ spectra
primaries are right lined prismatic coloured fringes, having 
the colours composing each fringe always in the same position 
with respect to each other.
Binaries are also rectilinear fringes, but are always 
formed into two classes with respect to the position of the colours 
of which they are composed; which classes are always divided 
by a central band: those on each side, (consisting generally 
of from five to eight,) having the red colour of each fringe 
turned outwards or <u>from<\u> the central band. 
primaries may be subdivided into two Species. 
1st Those composed of the brightest & most intense colours 
of all the various phenomena, are produced by a considerable 
degree of pressure untill part of the contiguous surfaces of 
the two glass plates are brought into contact; & thereby forming 
an extreamly small angle between them; these fringes 
extend to indefinite distances from the  vertex of the Angle 
or point of contact, & are best seen in clear Day light. 
2d. Those formed without pressure, when the two conti-
guous surfaces of plane glass slips are  parallel; are com-
posed of feeble light & shade only without any perceptible 
colour. these fringes which are much narrower than

* What is meant by rectilinear phenomena, are those fringes 
whether primary or Binary, that are formed between the 
surfaces of the best plate glass, in contradistinction to those 
formed between lenses: altho strictly & mathematically speaking, 
none have ever been seen perfectly streight, & without some 
irregularities; because it may be safely pronounced impracti
cable, to polish any surface perfectly flat. 
+ Altho this word is not new, it it unavoidably employed 
in a new sense. <\s>
